millsfield:images_texts:
AMERICAN AIRLINES
FLAGSHIP
INFORMATION
America's Leading Airline

FOR A MORE
ENJOYABLE FLIGHT
In this flight packet, you will find many
things of interest. For example, there is a
map for your use in locatng your position
from the air ... a complete booklet that
answers practically all the questions you
may have about your Flagship and how it
flies... postcards... and much more. This
packet is for you, so why not take it with
you as a souvenir of your flight.
However, there may be something you
want but don't see. If so, just push the call
button and your stewardess will be at your
side in a moment to fill your wish. If you
want to send a telegram, just ask her-she'll
give you the blanks and see that it's sent at
the next airport. She will also help you plan
your continuing or return trip with the aid
of the In-Flight Reservations form in this
packet. In fact, she will be a constant
source of assistance throughout the flight.
On the ground, as in the air, you'll find
AMeriCan AIRLINES ready, and willing, to
serve you whetner its plannig a vacation
in Mexico, or arranging to have a rental
car awaiting your arrival at the airport. All
you have to do is ask at any Reservations
or Ticket Office. You will find AMERICAN
AIRLInes a complete travel service with
but a single purpose - to make your trip
more enjoyable.

properties.sfomuseum:description: Flight information packet issued by American Airlines, comprising:a. folder titled “Flagship Information / America’s Leading Airline” with full color photographic image on front and rear cover depicting three male pilots and two female flight attendants standing on airfield in front of aircraft; tri-fold format with three pockets containing inserts b-l;b, c, d. airmail courtesy label; blue and red with “AA” eagle logo and text, “Air Mail / American Airlines”;e, f. circular luggage label; orange, blue, and white with airline servicemark;g. postcard depicting full color photographic image of passengers deplaning from aircraft “Flagship Boston” on airfield;h. inflight information pamphlet titled “Welcome aboard / American Airlines” depicting color illustration of female flight attendant in blue uniform and hat; multipage booklet;i. brochure promoting car rental with Hertz; yellow cover with black and white illustration of people walking toward a car; tri-fold format;j. comment card; blue and red cover; bi-fold format;k. timetable effective March 1, 1953; folded multipage booklet;l. system route map full color illustration of woman and two children ascending ramp stairs, waving toward viewer.
